text: Chapter number 3, as you've got your place there, I want you to also, if you would, hold your place in Ephesians chapter number 5. We will make some reference back to the 5th chapter of the book of Ephesians, and really into the first few verses of chapter number 6 this morning as well, as we look at this portion of Scripture. You'll remember that in Colossians 3, verses 5 through 14, as we've been studying over the last several weeks, that we have been instructed to crucify our flesh, to put off the old man and his deeds, and to put on the new man. We find that the process of sanctification is in view in this passage of Scripture, and I believe that we are given practical insight regarding our walk with the Lord. Truly, we find that we have the responsibility to walk in the Spirit so that we do not fulfill the lust of the flesh. And we find that as we look at this portion of Scripture that we've studied over the last several weeks, you continue to read through the passage, and you find even as we looked last week at verses 15 through 17, that it appears quite obvious that as we take heed to the instruction given in verses 5 through 14, that it will have an impact on our behavior. When we crucify our flesh, when we put off the old man, the flesh, and the deeds, and we put on the new man, and we walk in the Spirit, we find that it will impact, it will affect the way that we live, it will affect our behavior. I've often said over the years that belief impacts behavior. It is true also that behavior reveals belief. And we find this morning that as we look at this portion of Scripture that even as we discussed last week in verses 15 through 17, we noted the behavior of God's people in God's house. And I'm thankful that God gives us instruction for behavior in the house of God. And we find that as we looked at this portion last week, we said that our behavior in the church house should be characterized by five things. By peace, by unity, devotion. Let the Word of Christ dwell in you richly in all wisdom. We talked about that devotion and how appropriate to hear Brother Savalle share about the Word of God making such an impact in the believers in the church. And that's how it's supposed to work, amen? And so we see peace and unity and devotion, and then purpose. All that we do is to bring honor and glory to the Lord Jesus Christ that He alone would be exalted. And then finally, we looked at that last idea from really all three of the verses that our behavior should be characterized by praise. And we are to enter into His gates with thanksgiving. Let everything that hath breath praise the Lord, praise ye the Lord. He is worthy of our worship. He is worthy of our praise. And so we find that the first aspect of our behavior that is dealt with in this portion of Scripture is with regard to our behavior in the church house. This morning we'll be focusing on verses 18 through 21, and as we look at these few verses of Scripture, we find that the focus now shifts to the home. We know, we understand biblically that it was God that designed the home. You understand that all the way back in the Garden of Eden, as we read the book of Genesis, that God instituted the home. I'm thankful that the home is not the idea of man, that we're not relying upon the instruction of man. We find that God is the author of the home. He's intended for the home to follow the instruction that He has provided in His Word. And we find that as we would take the instruction that He's provided in His Word with regard to the home, I believe this morning that we can have a home that thrives, not just survival mode. You know, there are a lot of homes in America today that are on survival mode. There are a lot of homes...listen, the home is under attack. Amen? We see it all around our society. We see it everywhere in which we go. You do not have to look very far. It's very apparent that the home is under serious attack. We understand that the enemy attacks everything that God designs. Amen? And God designed the home, and we find that the home is now under attack. And we find that as we consider the home, and we consider this which is in front of us this morning, I believe that we can have a home where the Lord is honored. And that's the title for the message this morning, a home where the Lord is honored. I want you to notice with me as we look at this portion of Scripture, begin with me in verse number 18. The Bible says this, Wives, submit yourselves unto your own husbands, as it is fit in the Lord. Husbands, love your wives, and be not bitter against them. Children, obey your parents in all things, for this is well-pleasing unto the Lord. Fathers, provoke not your children to anger, lest they be discouraged. I believe this morning that a strong church is made up of strong families. That's one of the reasons why the family is under attack. Because as the family breaks down, the church also breaks down. I believe this morning that before we ever have revival in the church, that we have to have revival in our homes. And I believe that God has given us instruction as we look at this portion of Scripture. It seems so easy, and really the thoughts this morning are quite basic. Number one, if you're taking notes, think of this. Instruction has been provided. Instruction has been provided. Now, I want to say this right at the beginning of the message. I am thankful that God has given instruction. We ought to agree this morning that our God has been faithful to provide us with instruction. Have you ever attempted to put something together? Maybe you've purchased something. Maybe you've made the decision to purchase something from IKEA, and you got it, and there's 5,000 little pieces and all of this stuff that you need to put together. And you say, man, alive, this is a project. And I heard about the president of IKEA, all of the senior management got together for his birthday to provide him with a cake, and they gave him a couple of eggs and some oil and some water and some flour and said, here's your birthday cake, right? And it was quite comical. But the reality is that sometimes instructions can be one thing. We look at them and say, what in the world? Right, Joseph? He does some projects with me. And sometimes I look at the instructions and I'm like, I don't get it. It just does not make sense to me. I'm not following what I'm supposed to do here. What is this part for? What is this thing for? When we think about the instructions that God has provided to us, we ought to be thankful that our God has been faithful to provide us with this instruction. And as we consider this morning, not only the reality that God has been faithful, but I also want you to think about this and acknowledge this truth this morning, that the instruction is indeed from God. This is not just Paul's instruction to the families in Colossae. This is not just my instruction to the folks in our church this morning. No, this is God's instruction. We believe this morning in the inspiration of God's word, that all scripture is given by inspiration of God and is what is profitable. And I believe this morning that as we consider the word of God that is before us, that we must acknowledge that this is the word of God. And as God has given, we're not going to attack, well, Paul just didn't understand in this. No, it's God's word. Amen. And when we acknowledge that it's God's word and this instruction is from God, and we understand this morning that it's profitable, then I believe that we also would come to this point, and perhaps I would say this, we should agree this morning that God knows best. Would you agree with that? God knows best. He is the author of the home. He designed it. He instituted the home. And so who would know better about the home than God? Right? Listen, I understand this morning, there are a lot of books that have been written by a lot of very good authors about the home. I understand that. And there are some valuable things that you can glean from some of those books that are out there, but I would say this, that those truths must be in line with the truth that's provided in this book. Because God is the author of the home. He is the designer, and therefore He knows best. And when we agree this morning at the very onset of the message, when we consider this instruction that's provided, is that first, I'm going to be thankful that God's given the instruction. I'm going to acknowledge that it's from God, and I'm also going to agree that He knows best. Then it helps us as we approach this portion of Scripture. Amen? Because all of a sudden, our perspective and our entrance into the verses that we see are going to be received in a different manner. Because we say, this is God's Word, and God knows best. And I'm thankful that He's provided the instruction. Notice with me, as we consider the instruction that's been provided, first we see in verse number 18, He addresses the wives. He says this, wives, submit yourselves unto your own husbands. And it says this as it is fit in the Lord. The word submit, we understand it to be a word that means to arrange under rank. In fact, it would be a word that would be often used with regard to military type of reference. But we find that it means to arrange under rank. It does not mean slavery, amen? It means to arrange under rank. And we consider this truth that's been given here, we must understand that our God is a God of order. Everything that our God does... is with order. You read Genesis chapter number one as you read about the creation of all that he did, and you see the order in creation, and you find that God says in the church in Corinth that everything is to be done decently and in order. Why? Because our God is a God of order. You find that the enemy is the designer of chaos and confusion. He is not about order, but our God is about order. And so therefore, as he's providing this instruction to us, we find that he's giving us order for the home. And as we consider, first he speaks to the wives about this subject of submission, and then he finishes the verse by saying, as it is fit in the Lord. It is fitting as a wife would fulfill her responsibility to submit to her own husband. It's pleasing to God. We find that as you not only consider that it's pleasing to God, I believe it also would carry with it the idea that it is appropriate in God's eyes. In other words, it's not for a wife to submit to do something that would be contrary to what God's word has said. That some husband can say, well, you're supposed to submit, and so do this, so on and so forth. That's not the idea of submission. And really what happens is the enemy wants to get that little thought in your head so that when you hear the word submit, you have both arms out in resistance. But when we take the approach that this is from God, and that God knows best, and that God has been faithful to give the instruction, all of a sudden, I'm going to receive the instruction and understand that it is best for me to follow the instruction. Look over, I asked you to keep your place in Ephesians 5. Notice in Ephesians 5, in verses 22 through 24, we find that God gives instruction to the believers in Ephesus. Again, he begins with the wives. He says this, submit yourselves unto your own husbands. Look at what he says, as unto the Lord. Understanding, again, that God has given order. And I know that there's some that say, I just don't wanna, I just can't submit to him, and so on and so forth. You understand that he's responsible to God. And as you submit and you fulfill your responsibility to God to submit, then that responsibility ends with the husband. And really, there's a valuable level of protection for the wife as she submits unto her husband as unto the Lord. Notice in verse 23, for the husband is the head of the wife even as Christ is the head of the church, and he is the savior of the body. Therefore, as the church is subject unto Christ, we'll let the wives be to their own husbands in everything. And so we find that the instruction is provided first to the wives. Number two, to the husbands. Notice back in Colossians 3, in verse number 19, the Bible says this, husbands. It says, love your wives and be not bitter against them. We find that the truth in Ephesians 5 with regard to this instruction for husbands to love our wives, it says this, it gives us the manner in which we're to love our wives. In Ephesians 5, in verse number 25, husbands, love your wives even as Christ also loved the church and gave himself for it. That's the highest form of love. It's the Greek word agape. It's the word that's denoted, that's used regarding the love of God. And we find that we are to love our wives, husbands, as Christ loved the church and gave himself for it. It is a sacrificial love. And let me say this this morning, maybe perhaps as a question, does your wife, husbands, does your wife know that you love her in this manner? Does she know that you love her? And then it said this, if any man have a quarrel against any, even as Christ forgave you, so also do ye. They're a blessing from God, and we have been, for a season of time, we have been entrusted by God to instruct our children, to bring them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord, and we need to be careful to understand that they're a blessing from God and that we play a vital role in their development, and that we help them to understand much about who God is and how God operates. The reality is that much of the Bible is very easy to understand, and when you couple that with the fact that we have the Holy Spirit of God that is the Teacher that dwells within us and He illumines the Scriptures to us, it makes it that much easier for us to understand the Word of God. And this morning, I don't think anyone that's here could honestly say, I just don't understand, because the instruction is easy to understand. So it leads me to my final thought this morning. Instruction must be embraced and applied. Instruction must be embraced and applied. The instruction has been provided. Instruction can be understood, but can I say this this morning? Understanding does not equal applying. We can understand something and not apply it, correct? We can understand something and not apply it. So understanding does not equal applying. But this morning, when we look at this portion of Scripture, if we truly desire to have a home where the Lord is honored, where we have a harmonious home, where we aren't just in survival mode, but we're thriving with the blessing of God, and we're going through life enjoying all that God has designed for us to enjoy, then we must apply the truth that has been given. It's not enough to just say that God's provided the instruction. Oh, we're thankful that He's provided it. What a tremendous blessing. I mean, can you imagine if God did not provide instruction for your home? We wouldn't know how to behave. We wouldn't know who's supposed to do what, and so on and so forth, and it could be very chaotic. But God has graciously provided the instruction, and it's very easy to understand. But understanding does not equal applying, and we find that I must embrace this truth, and as I embrace the instruction, I then apply it in my life. The wives apply the truth of verse 18. The husbands applying the truth of verse number 19. The children applying the truth of verse number 20. The father's parents applying the truth of verse number 21. And listen, here's what I find this morning. My flesh and your flesh probably have a hard time with some of the instruction that's provided here, but that's why the preceding text is so important. Mortify, therefore, your members which are upon the earth. Literally crucify your flesh. Put off the old man, all of these things. Put on the new man with all of these things. Now your behavior in the church house is going to be characterized by peace and unity and devotion and purpose and praise, and now your home is going to be a home where each individual is fulfilling the plan that God has. Wives will have a much easier time submitting when they know that their husbands love them, that their husbands are walking with God, that their husbands have put off the old man and put on the new man and are walking in the power of the Holy Spirit of God. Children are gonna have a much easier time obeying their parents as they know that their parents love them and that their parents are seeking the face of God and desiring to please God. There are times in which perhaps we can tell our children, give them an answer with regard to something that they desire to do, and we can take them directly to some verses of Scripture and explain to them why we're not going to engage in such and such of behavior and so on and so forth. And there are other times that we just might be like, hey, listen, can you just trust me on this? We just don't have a piece about this. And if our children know that we're walking with God, if our children know that we love them, that we're not seeking to provoke them to anger, that we're not living a life of hypocrisy, that we're not seeking to be contentious and inconsistent, then they can have an easier time of obeying. But if we do all of that without putting off and putting on, we're gonna struggle because it's gonna get old real fast in the flesh trying to do that. It's very interesting to me that the truth that is given to us, the instruction provided in verses 18 through 21, in this portion of Colossians is preceded by that which we've dealt with in the last several weeks. It's also of interest and noteworthy that in Ephesians five and six, the portion that we were looking at earlier, where the same instruction is provided, I want you to be understanding this morning of the preceding passage that deals with this truth in Ephesians five. Before he gets to wives and husbands and children as he's addressing the church in Ephesus, he says this in verse number 18 of Ephesians five. And be not drunk with wine, wherein is excess. Notice, but be filled with the Spirit. I believe this morning that what is summarized in those few words at the end of verse number 18, but be filled with the Spirit, is what is illustrated to us in detail in Colossians three verses five through 14. Mortify therefore your members which are upon the earth. Put off the old man, put on the new. That's the idea of being filled with the Spirit of God. That's the rubber meets the road truth of okay, how do I do this? The application. We find that he says, but be filled with the Spirit. Notice, speaking to yourselves in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody in your heart to the Lord, giving thanks always for all things unto God and for the Father in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, submitting yourselves one to another in the fear of God. Then he addresses the wives and the husbands and the children. And so as I'm walking in the Spirit, it is God who enables me to apply the instruction that he's given me with regard to the home. I can't do it in my own power. You understand something this morning? You can't live the Christian life in your own power. You can try for a little while. You're gonna get frustrated. You really are. You're gonna just get sideways in life and you're gonna get frustrated because you're trying to do it in your own power. Paul said, I know that in me that is in my flesh dwelleth no good thing, right? He says, the things that I would, I do not. The things that I would not, that I do. Listen, you try to live the Christian life in your own power and we become miserable. But it's amazing when God, when we come to that place of surrender, submission to God, walking in the Spirit and how he enables us to implement, to apply the instruction that he has provided. This morning, I would hope that each and every one of us would stand and testify and say, I want a home where the Lord is honored. I want a home where God is honored. The home, I've often said this over the years, is that haven, that safe place. I remember when I worked in the corporate world, it's a little bit different now as a pastor of a church. My office is kind of a haven of rest as well until some people wanna meet. No, I'm just teasing. And this morning, if you wanna have a home that honors God, if you desire that, we understand that God's provided the instruction and we ought to be thankful for that. It's easy to understand, but oh, how we must embrace it and apply it. And when we do, I believe the result will be a home where the Lord is honored. Maybe this morning for our invitation, we need to have some families just gather together and pray together. Maybe visit the altar together, husbands and wives. Oh, that God would help me in this area so that we can have a home where the Lord is honored. Let's pray. Father, how we love you and how we thank you for the instruction that you've provided. We acknowledge this morning that this is your word. And you designed the home and you've provided the instruction for each member in the home. I believe this morning it's simple. It's easy to understand. But oh, how we understand this morning that to understand something does not mean to apply something. We're challenged by the truth of James 1 that we would be doers of the word and not hearers only. Our homes are under attack. If we're not careful, we begin to listen to what the world says about how a home should operate. We begin to receive counsel from individuals that would speak to us about the role that we should play in our homes instead of listening to the voice of God. I pray that you'd move and work this morning in each family that's present. Perhaps they would have the opportunity to come to this altar as a family and just pray. God, we pray that you would have your will and way, that decisions would be made this morning that would honor you. We will thank you for all that you'll do for it's in Christ's name we pray.
